metadata.title: Port Sulphur Weather and Hydrologic Data
metadata.location: Port Sulphur, Louisiana (Mississippi River Mile 48.6 AHP)
metadata.description: Comprehensive weather, hydrologic, and flood risk data for Port Sulphur terminal operations

seasonal_discharge_patterns.description: Mississippi River discharge patterns at Port Sulphur based on regional monitoring data

discharge_cfs.description: Sustained high discharges from snowmelt and spring rainfall

annual_cycle.operational_impact: Most challenging conditions; extreme current velocities; enhanced tug requirements; construction severely constrained
annual_cycle.vessel_operations: Maximum draft capability but challenging handling
annual_cycle.construction_suitability: Precluded for marine construction; heavy structure placement possible

notable_events.description: Exceptional event with >6 months sustained high water

notable_events.note: Establishes design envelope for extreme events

water_velocity_fps.description: Optimal conditions for operations and construction

annual_cycle.operational_impact: Optimal period for terminal operations and construction; prime construction window July - early September
annual_cycle.construction_suitability: Preferred window for major projects and maintenance

hurricane_overlap.note: Requires balance between construction efficiency and weather risk management

discharge_cfs.description: Minimum river stages and reduced velocities

annual_cycle.operational_impact: Potential draft restrictions but optimal for underwater work; competitive advantage for deep-water terminals
annual_cycle.vessel_operations: Draft restrictions for shallow terminals; Port Sulphur maintains capability
annual_cycle.construction_suitability: Ideal for underwater construction, inspection, and precision maintenance

notable_events.note: Demonstrated strategic value of deep-water access

summer_pattern.typical_events: Several inches in short time periods
summer_pattern.impact: Potential for rapid onset flooding; drainage system challenges

tropical_events.impact: Regional flooding extending beyond immediate storm areas
tropical_events.compound_risk: Often coincides with elevated river stages creating compound flooding scenarios

temperature.note: Specific temperature ranges not quantified in synthesis document; referenced in operational context only

cold_fronts.impact: Challenging vessel operations; temporary suspension of cargo handling

fog_conditions.formation_mechanism: Radiational cooling combined with river surface moisture
fog_conditions.typical_duration: Early morning through mid-morning; occasionally all day
fog_conditions.visibility_threshold: Dense fog <0.25 miles requires vessel movement suspension
fog_conditions.operational_impact: Vessel navigation restrictions; cargo handling may be limited; economic impact accumulates over fog season

hurricane_and_storm_history.location_risk: Primary threat zone for Gulf of Mexico tropical systems

major_events.name: Hurricane Katrina
major_events.note: Specific Port Sulphur figure from federal assessments; NHC gives 15-19 ft for parish level
major_events.impact: Catastrophic damage to sulfur facility structures; ~80% housing units affected in parish

gauge_data.note: Gauge failed before peak; many gauges failed near peak

sources: FEMA Wind-Water Line (WWL) Data Collection (June 9, 2006) - Port Sulphur Sheet 50
USGS SIR 2009-5230 - High-water mark based surge surface
major_events.data_quality: NHC TCR provides parish-level surge (15-19 ft); site-specific depths require FEMA WWL maps and USGS HWM data

major_events.name: Hurricane Isaac
major_events.impact: Demonstrated effectiveness of post-Katrina levee improvements
major_events.observations: Port Sulphur is good; Buras is good; Venice is good
major_events.note: Visible water lines on levees showed protection systems held during significant storm surge

major_events.name: Hurricane Ida
major_events.impact: Additional testing of regional infrastructure resilience
major_events.note: Debris from this event remains visible years later, demonstrating long-term impacts

flood_protection.system: Federal levee system (HSDRRS - Hurricane and Storm Damage Risk Reduction System)
flood_protection.100_year_definition: 1% annual chance of occurrence or exceedance
flood_protection.note: Based on combined storm size, intensity, and track probabilities; not solely wind speed category

100_year_event.description: Risk reduction from storm surge with 1% annual exceedance probability
100_year_event.factors: Combined chances of storm size, intensity (pressure), and track
100_year_event.note: Different combinations can result in same 100-year surge event

design_considerations: Possible increases in storm severity or frequency
storm_surge_models.saffir_simpson_note: Wind speed alone cannot reliably describe storm surge; original 1972 Saffir-Simpson scale inadequate for surge prediction

primary_sources: FEMA Wind-Water Line (WWL) maps - Port Sulphur Sheet 50
CPRA (Louisiana Coastal Protection and Restoration Authority) storm surge modeling

compound_flooding_risks.description: Unique compound flooding scenarios from storm surge + river stage + precipitation
factors: Timing and interaction of multiple factors

post_katrina_improvements.validation: Visible water lines showed systems held during significant surge events

historical_flood_timeline.impact: Levee improvements effective; no major damage reported
Record-approaching peak flows; establishes design envelope
Valuable data on infrastructure performance under extreme sustained conditions
Infrastructure resilience tested; long-term debris impacts
Industry-wide draft restrictions; demonstrated deep-water terminal advantages

prime_construction.conditions: River velocities 1.5-2.5 fps; relatively stable weather before peak hurricane activity
prime_construction.constraints: Hurricane season overlap requires flexible scheduling

underwater_work.conditions: Low current velocities 1.2-1.8 fps; reduced river stages
underwater_work.advantages: Precision work capability; access to normally submerged areas
underwater_work.constraints: Fog, cold fronts, winter weather require enhanced safety protocols

vessel_operations_optimal.conditions: Manageable currents 2.0-3.0 fps; predictable water levels
vessel_operations_optimal.advantages: Standard navigation procedures; consistent cargo handling

vessel_operations_challenging.conditions: Extreme velocities 3.5-5.0 fps; high water stages
vessel_operations_challenging.requirements: Enhanced tug assistance; specialized mooring procedures

river_monitoring.stations: Downstream monitoring stations with regional scaling factors for Port Sulphur
river_monitoring.uses: Operational planning; construction scheduling; vessel operations

weather_forecasting.regional_coordination: Fog reporting and visibility monitoring network

monitoring_and_forecasting.integration: Combined river condition and weather monitoring enables comprehensive operational planning

deep_water_access.benefit: Operational capability during winter low water when shallow terminals face restrictions
deep_water_access.market_impact: Revenue opportunities when competitors face draft restrictions

year_round_operations.seasonal_optimization: Different operational modes for high/moderate/low water periods

data_sources_and_references.regional_monitoring: Mississippi River downstream monitoring stations with Port Sulphur scaling factors

key_findings.seasonal_patterns: Remarkably consistent annual cycle: high water (Mar-Jun), optimal (Jul-Oct), low water (Nov-Feb)
primary_risks: Hurricane season overlap with optimal construction period
Extreme spring high water velocities (3.5-5.0 fps)
Winter fog reducing visibility 15-25 days annually
strategic_advantages: Deep-water capability during low water periods
key_findings.critical_infrastructure: Post-Katrina levee improvements validated through Isaac (2012) and Ida (2021)
key_findings.extreme_events_dataset: 2018 peak flows (650k cfs), 2019 extended flood (>6 months), 2023 extreme low (131k cfs) provide comprehensive design envelope
